captions.text: [door opens]

- HEY.
- HOW YOU DOING?

- GOOD, HOW ARE YOU?
- GOOD.
- I OWE YOU MONEY.

- YOU GONNA PAY
THE WHOLE BALANCE?

- YEAH, WHICH IS 360? YEAH.
- YEP.

- HOW MUCH WOULD YOU SAY YOU
SPEND IN EXPENSES EVERY MONTH?

- THE MONTHLY EXPENSES ARE
PRIMARILY BUSINESS EXPENSES.

- MISCELLANEOUS STUFF
FOR THE KIDS,

BE IT FIELD TRIPS,
LUNCH MONEY--
- GAS MONEY.

- 60, 80, MAYBE 100 BUCKS
A WEEK IN GAS.

- ELECTRICITY.
I HAVE INSURANCE.

- DENTAL INSURANCE,
HEALTH INSURANCE.

- MEDICINE.
- MEDICINES FOR THE KIDS.

- AND AS ONE BILL
GETS PAID OFF--

- THE NEXT MONTH,
IT'S MORE MONEY.

- FOR FOUR PEOPLE TO GO
TO THE MOVIES, IT'S OVER 100--
- 150 FOR PHONES.

- A LOT OF LITTLE EXPENSES
AND THEN BIG EXPENSES.
- WOULD I BE ABLE TO DO, LIKE,

A SWAP OF MACHINES
TO GO TOWARDS THIS?

- EVERY MONTH, WE SPEND
ANYWHERE FROM $2,800 TO $3,500.

- SOMETIMES I'M LEFT
WITH HARDLY ANYTHING.
- SOMETIMES IT'S NAIL-BITING.
IT'S A ROLLER COASTER.

- I HAVE ALL THIS MASSIVE DEBT
BEHIND ME,
AND IT FEELS SO OVERWHELMING.

- WE ALL WANT
TO GET THE MOST OUT OF LIFE.
- [laughs]
- A GREAT FAMILY,
AN EDUCATION,

A BUSINESS,
A HOME...
- IT'S A THREE-BEDROOM/FOUR.

- BUT FOR A GROWING NUMBER
OF AMERICANS,

THE PRICE OF GETTING AHEAD
IS HIGHER
BECAUSE OF A FINANCIAL SYSTEM

THAT LEAVES MILLIONS
UNDERSERVED.

- YOU JUST HAVE
TO KIND OF TUCK YOUR CHIN

TO YOUR CHEST
AND KEEP GOING FORWARD.

- DON'T GIVE UP
EVEN WHEN YOU WANT TO.

- THERE'S NOT EVER THE OPTION
TO NOT MAKE IT WORK.
I HAVE TO.

- YOU READY?
- YEAH.
LET'S RACE.

- [laughs]
YOU GOT NO CHANCE, BABY.
- I GREW UP DIRT POOR.

WE WERE ON WELFARE.
WE WERE ON FOOD STAMPS.

I REMEMBER THE FIRST DAY
OF SCHOOL.

YOU KNOW, EVERYBODY'S
ALWAYS GOT THEIR BEST GEAR ON.

EVERYBODY'S READY
FOR THE FIRST DAY OF SCHOOL,

AND MY BEST GEAR CAME
FROM GOODWILL.
I OFTEN LOOK BACK AT MY LIFE.

FROM AN EARLY AGE,
THERE WAS A LOT

OF WANTING
AND DISAPPOINTMENT.
- DESPITE HIS TOUGH PAST,

JUSTIN'S BUILT
A SMALL PRODUCTION COMPANY

AND WANTS TO START A LIFE
WITH HIS GIRLFRIEND, BRITTANY.

- NOW THAT I'M AN ADULT
AND I'M MAKING IT,

I WANT TO CARRY MY WHOLE FAMILY
ON MY BACK,

SO NOBODY EVER HAS
TO WANT OR WORRY.

I LOVE YOU.
HAVE A GOOD DAY.
SEE YOU LATER.
I LOVE BRITTANY.

I'M GONNA BUY A RING,
AND I'M GONNA MAKE HER MY WIFE.

I'M GONNA DO THE THINGS
THAT WILL TAKE US THERE.
[beep]
- HE MAKES A GOOD LIVING

SHOOTING VIDEOS
FOR CORPORATE CLIENTS.
- I SEE A LOT OF POTENTIAL

WHERE WE'RE AT
AND WHERE WE'RE GOING.
- BUT WHILE BUSINESS IS GOOD,
JUSTIN'S AT A DISADVANTAGE.

- I GET CHECKS FROM CLIENTS,
AND I LEAVE

THE LUSTER AND GRANDEUR
OF DOWNTOWN,

AND I GO UPTOWN RIGHT
INTO THE CHECK CASHING PLACE.

I'M DOING GOOD.
I'M TIRED, BUT I'M GOOD.

- JUSTIN IS
1 OF 70 MILLION AMERICANS

WHO LACK ACCESS TO THE
TRADITIONAL FINANCIAL SYSTEM.
AND AS THAT NUMBER GROWS,

IT INCLUDES
MORE AND MORE PEOPLE

WHO ONCE LIVED
IN THE MAINSTREAM.

- VERY GOOD, OKAY,
NOW WRITE THAT NUMBER DOWN
'CAUSE WE'RE GONNA SUBTRACT.

SO WE REALLY--
- 236 TAKE AWAY 149.
MY TOTAL ANSWER IS 87.
- [snaps fingers]

YOU COOKING WITH CRISCO.
- ALL RIGHT.

- TAKE YOU A MINUTE TO COOK
THE MEAL,
BUT YOU DOING A GOOD JOB.

YOU HAVE TO BE
YOUR CHILD'S FIRST TEACHER.

I TOLD YOU, YOU COULD DO IT,
AND I BELIEVED IN YOU.

YOU JUST HAVE TO APPLY YOURSELF
AND WORK HARD.

MY MOM TAUGHT ME,
"PAY WHAT YOU OWE AND SAVE."
SO I SAVED.
SAVINGS ACCOUNTS, 401(k)s,

CREDIT CARDS
WITH WONDERFUL LIMITS.

I WANTED TO HAVE SOMETHING
TO LEAVE FOR MY DAUGHTER.

WE KNOW WE NEED
AN HOUR OF MATH EVERY NIGHT,

AND WE KNOW WE NEED AT LEAST
30 MINUTES OF READING EVERY DAY.

I WANT HER TO BE ABLE
TO FIND

SUCCESS IN WHATEVER
HER DREAMS ARE.

I CHOSE TO PUT HER
IN PRIVATE SCHOOL

BECAUSE I DON'T WANT TO EVER
COMPROMISE ON HER EDUCATION.

I LOVE YOU. HAVE A GREAT DAY.
- LOVE YOU.

- BE GOOD.
GOOD LUCK ON YOUR TEST.
- TIFFANY WORKED AS A NURSE

TO PROVIDE FOR HER FAMILY
AND BUILT

A NEST EGG
FOR HER DAUGHTER'S FUTURE.

- MY 401(k)
WAS ALMOST 100,000.
LIFE WAS GOOD.

I WAS LIVING
THE AMERICAN DREAM.

- HEY, HONEY?
- YEAH?

- YOU WERE RIGHT.
THERE'S A LITTLE TOO MUCH WATER.
[laughter]
- WELL, THEY'LL BE CREPES.

- SOME OF 'EM WILL BE CREPES,
AND SOME WILL BE PANCAKES.

- DUDE, I LIKE IT.
- [laughs]

- WHEN MELISSA
FIRST MET ALEX,

HE HAD A CAREER
IN THE MUSIC INDUSTRY

AND WAS DOING
WHAT HE LOVED MOST.
- I LOVE THIS THING.
- AFTER ONE OF THE SHOWS,
I WENT UP AND TALKED TO ALEX.
AND WE KIND OF HIT IT OFF.

- NO "KIND OF" ABOUT IT.
WE JUST HIT IT OFF.
- WE HIT IT OFF.

ABOUT TEN WEEKS
AFTER OUR FIRST DATE,
HE ASKED ME TO MARRY HIM.

JUST LIKE EVERYTHING ELSE
IN OUR LIFE,

THE FAMILY THING HAPPENED
PRETTY QUICKLY.

- WITH TWO KIDS
AND TWO INCOMES,

ALEX AND MELISSA HAD
A HEALTHY, HAPPY HOME.

- TIMES WERE GOOD.
EVERYONE WAS DOING WELL.

AND THEN OUR REALITY CHANGED
OVERNIGHT.

- THEIR SON WAS
DIAGNOSED WITH AUTISM.

SHORTLY AFTER,
ALEX WAS DIAGNOSED
WITH MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS.

- IT WAS TERRIFYING,
AND THEN WHAT HAPPENED WAS,
IS I FOCUSED ON THE KIDS.

DOES IT MATTER?
- YES.

- [chuckles]
WHICH ONE DO YOU WANT TO GET?

- GO BURLINGTON.
- BURLINGTON?

- GO BURLINGTON.
- NOT TODAY. NOT TODAY. THEY--

WHAT ARE WE DOING TODAY, JONAH?
LOOK AT MOMMY.

- STAY HOME.
- STAY HOME.
- I CAN TELL YOU TO GO,

AND I CAN SCHEDULE IT,
BUT IF YOU DON'T GO--

- MA, YOU GOT--
HE HAS TO TEST YOUR EYES.
I HAD JUST GOTTEN A NEW JOB.
HE HAS TO--
I HAD STEADY INCOME.

BUT THEN MY MOM WAS DIAGNOSED
WITH CANCER.
THAT'S MY NUMBER ONE PATIENT.

HOW CAN I TAKE CARE
OF SOMEBODY ELSE

WHEN I HAVE MY MOM
SUFFERING AT HOME?

- TIFFANY DECIDED
TO LEAVE HER JOB,

SO SHE COULD FOCUS FULL-TIME
ON HER MOTHER'S HEALTH.

- I THOUGHT THAT I COULD
COME BACK TO THE WORKFORCE

AND JUST PICK UP
WHERE I LEFT OFF.

- THE PICTURE
OF THE FINANCIALLY UNSTABLE
IS A PICTURE OF YOU AND ME
BUT FOR A COUPLE OF BREAKS.

- BETWEEN ALEX'S ILLNESS
AND JONAH'S DIAGNOSIS,
THIS BECAME THIS HUGE EXPENSE

THAT WE HAD
NO CONTINGENCY PLAN FOR,
WE HAD NO SAVINGS FOR.

- ALEX'S ILLNESS
AFFECTED HIS ABILITY TO WORK,

AND HE WAS FORCED TO GIVE UP
HIS JOB.

SO THEY DID WHAT MANY AMERICANS
DO AT THEIR BANK.

- IF A BILL CAME UP
AND WE NEEDED TO PAY
FOR THE POWER OR THE CABLE,
WE KNEW WE COULD GO AHEAD

AND WRITE A CHECK
AND IT WOULD CLEAR.

- WHEN A CUSTOMER
WITHDRAWS MORE MONEY

THAN THEY HAVE
IN THEIR ACCOUNT,

THEY CAN GIVE
THEIR BANK PERMISSION

TO COVER THAT COST
WITH AN ADDED FEE.

THIS IS CALLED
OVERDRAFT PROTECTION.

- BANKS WERE INCREASINGLY
LOOKING FOR PROFITS

FROM THESE CLASSIC
CONSUMER CHECK ACCOUNTS.

- SOME CUSTOMERS
DIDN'T MAKE MONEY FOR BANKS,

SO THEY FOUND OTHER WAYS
TO MEET COSTS.
- WHAT MOST BANKS WERE DOING

AS A CUSTOMARY PRACTICE
WAS THIS CHECK REORDERING,

OR IT'S ALSO CALLED
HIGH-LOW CHECK SEQUENCING.

- WHEN ALEX AND MELISSA
PAID THEIR BILLS,

THEIR GROCERY AND STUDENT LOAN
CHECKS CLEARED OKAY,
BUT THE PRICE OF POWER WENT UP,

AND THAT BILL EMPTIED
THEIR ACCOUNT.
ONE OVERDRAFT FEE, $35.

BUT IF ALL THREE DEBTS POSTED
ON THE SAME DAY,

THEIR BANK HAD SOFTWARE
THAT REORDERED THEIR PURCHASES--

POWER BILL FIRST,
THEN LOAN, THEN GROCERIES.
THREE OVERDRAFT FEES, $105.
- THE FEES BECAME SO MUCH.

PAYDAY WOULD COME,
AND WE'D BE BACK TO ZERO.

- EVENTUALLY,
WHAT THE BANK WILL DO

IS BOOT THEM OUT OF THE SYSTEM
AND CLOSE THE ACCOUNT

BECAUSE THEY FEEL LIKE THEY'RE
NOT GONNA RECOUP THEIR DEBT.

- IF BANKS CAN'T KEEP
THOSE CUSTOMERS,

THERE'S AN ALTERNATIVE
THAT WILL.

EVERY YEAR, OVER 30 MILLION
AMERICANS USE CHECK CASHERS.

AND FOR MANY OF THEM,
THE SERVICE WORKS.

- THEY'RE OPEN LATER.
THEY REMEMBER MY NAME.

THEY'RE OFFERING
A "WE CAN GET YOU

WHAT YOU NEED RIGHT NOW"
KIND OF SOLUTION.

- A HUGE AMOUNT OF BUSINESS
GETS DONE AT CHECK CASHERS

BECAUSE PEOPLE CAN GET
THEIR MONEY RIGHT AWAY,

AND THEY NEED
THEIR MONEY RIGHT AWAY.
- WE'VE ALL HAD TO WAIT

A COUPLE OF DAYS
FOR A CHECK TO CLEAR.

IT'S BECAUSE
WHEN A BANK CLEARS A CHECK,

IT HAS TO BE SCANNED,
VERIFIED, AND PROCESSED

BY A SYSTEM THAT WAS BUILT
IN THE ERA OF ROTARY PHONES.
MOST WESTERN NATIONS HAVE

FOUND FASTER WAYS
TO CLEAR OUR FUNDS,
BUT NOT THE U.S.
SO AMERICANS HAVE TO WAIT.

- THREE TO FIVE DAYS FROM NOW
ISN'T ACCEPTABLE

FOR TENS OF MILLIONS
OF AMERICANS.

IF YOUR LIGHT'S GONNA
GO OUT TOMORROW,

YOU NEED TO BE ABLE
TO HAVE THAT CLEAR NOW.

- I'M NOT EXACTLY SURE
WHEN IT'S GONNA CLEAR,
AND I HAVE TO PAY MY BILLS.
YOU GO TO THE CHECK CASHER.

YOU GET THE MONEY BACK,
MINUS THE FEE.

YOU HAVE THAT MONEY IN
YOUR HANDS RIGHT AT THAT MOMENT.

- IT'S NOT
AN IRRATIONAL CHOICE.

IT'S JUST NOT
A PRODUCTIVE CHOICE,
AND IT'S A COSTLY CHOICE.
- UNDERSERVED AMERICANS SPEND

THE SAME PERCENT
OF THEIR INCOME
ON FEES AND INTEREST

AS THE TYPICAL AMERICAN FAMILY
SPENDS ON GROCERIES.

THAT AMOUNTS
TO $89 BILLION A YEAR.
- AND YOU ARE ALL SET.
- AS A WAY TO AVOID FEES,

ALEX AND MELISSA DECIDED
TO LIVE ON CASH.
- WE HAVE CASH ON HAND,

AND THAT'S THE MONEY
THAT WE HAVE.
THIS IS ALL WE CAN SPEND.

SO WHEN THE MONEY RUNS OUT,
THAT'S IT.

- ON PAYDAY,
IT'S GETTING TO THE PLACES,

SO I CAN GET
THE BILLS PAID ON TIME.
- HI, HOW ARE YOU?

- GOOD.
I'M HERE TO PAY THE POWER.
THANKS SO MUCH.

- TAKE CARE.
NOT A PROBLEM.
HAVE A GOOD ONE.

SOMETHING LIKE HAVING
A PART-TIME JOB.

- I PROBABLY SPEND
1/4 TANK TO 1/2 TANK

OF GAS DRIVING AROUND
AND PAYING BILLS.

- YOU'RE GONNA SPEND MORE MONEY
AND MORE TIME

DOING THINGS THAT PEOPLE
WHO ARE IN THE BANKING SYSTEM

TAKE FOR GRANTED
AND USUALLY DO FOR FREE.

YOU GO TO A CHECK CASHER,
YOU ARE AUTOMATICALLY

I JUST NEED TO PUT SOME MONEY

- MONEY IS BECOMING
MORE AND MORE DIGITAL,

WHICH MEANS THERE ARE
LESS PLACES THAT ACCEPT CASH.

THAT MAKES LIFE
FOR THE UNDERSERVED

- WE HAVE
A PREPAID DEBIT CARD,

AND THE MONEY

IT'S CASH THAT I DIRECTLY HAND
THE PEOPLE,

IT'S CONVENIENT,
YOU KNOW, IF YOU DON'T HAVE

- THERE'S THE TRANSACTION,
AND THERE'S A BUCK,

MAN, IT JUST KILLS YOU.

VERY QUICKLY,
YOU CAN LOSE

80 BUCKS A MONTH

- AND THAT'S JUST NOT
HOW YOU GET AHEAD.

IT'S NOT HOW YOU THINK
ABOUT THE FUTURE.

- THIS IS, LIKE,
FULLY HAND-STITCHED.
- WHAT?

- AND, YOU KNOW, I HAVE TO,

SO I FIGURED OUT

- AFTER SIX MONTHS,

- NOW I'M EXCITED.

BEAUTIFUL.
- CROSSBODY.

- LOVE IT, LOVE IT, LOVE IT.
- RIGHT?

AND WAIT, CHECK THIS OUT.
- PERFECT.

- I CAN SEE

MY COMPANY GROWING.

- YOU KNOW HOW TO GET OUT,

- YES, I DO.
- BUT BECAUSE STUDENT LOANS
HAVE WEAKENED HER CREDIT,
DEBBIE'S DREAM HAS A LIMIT.
BANKS USE CREDIT TO MEASURE

A PERSON'S ABILITY
TO REPAY A LOAN.

THEY LOOK AT A LIMITED SET
OF DATA:

LENGTH OF CREDIT HISTORY,
PAST LOAN PAYMENTS, AND DEBT.

IF YOU'VE NEVER TAKEN OUT A LOAN
OR LINE OF CREDIT,

YOU'RE INVISIBLE
TO THE CREDIT SCORING SYSTEM.

- I THOUGHT
I WAS BEING RESPONSIBLE
BY NOT HAVING CREDIT CARDS.

AND WE ALREADY HAD
A LOT OF FRIENDS WHO WERE

REALLY GETTING INTO THAT TRAP

SO YOU GOT TO GET

- WE TRIED TO BUY A CAR.

BE ABLE TO GET A MORTGAGE.
YOU SHOULD TRY TO GET A CAR."

OF FINANCIAL TRANSACTIONS

ONE UNDERTAKES THAT ARE NOT
ACTUALLY TRACKED
IN THE CREDIT SYSTEM.

AND SO PEOPLE WHO LOOKED LIKE
A HIGH FINANCIAL RISK
MIGHT NOT BE.

- WHEN A BANK

IT DOESN'T SEE

IT SEES A NUMBER.

AND IF THAT NUMBER'S DAMAGED

IT'S VERY DIFFICULT

- PEOPLE OFTEN JUDGE ME
ON THE CHOICES I'VE MADE

NOT KNOWING THE OPTIONS
THAT I HAD.
- JUSTIN HAD TO GROW UP FAST.

WHEN HE WAS A TEENAGER,
HIS FAMILY FALL APART.

WHATEVER I NEEDED, LIKE,

THAT HAD TO GET TAKEN CARE OF

I WASN'T GROWN ENOUGH YET

SO, YOU KNOW, WHAT DOES

- WHEN WE SET UP SHOOTS,

- AND WHILE HE'S TAKEN

- IT'S JUST FRUSTRATING

WE'VE WORKED REALLY HARD

IT'S SO HARD TO FIND A HOUSE.
- YEAH.

SO YOU GUYS DO

- YEAH.

- IN TERMS OF PRICING,

- THESE ARE MORE EXPENSIVE.

comments.text:
While I often argue that it is unfair to expect students to make the sorts 
of capital and time investment risks as an entrepreneur without the same 
potential financial rewards as a business brings, students are really 
making a greater risk given that they can't discharge their debt like a 
business can by declaring bankruptcy.  For many college graduates, if they 
could treat their post graduate collegiate career life as a business and 
their college debt as a business financial liability, they could have 
declared bankruptcy a long time ago and we would be seeing legitimate mass 
student debt discharges. ﻿

comments.text:
If I could give the lady running the handbag business 1 piece of advice.. 
It would be this: *Get clients* (particularly bigger business orders) *to 
pay upfront* ( *with* between 5 - 20% *discount* as an incentive to do so) 
That way you do not need credit from a bank.. and any fees or interest that 
you would pay if you had credit will be replaced by a small discount to 
your (high transaction value) customers... Job done.. Let the $$$ role in.. 
Its an obvious myth that a business like that handbag one cannot grow 
without credit from a bank.. Who needs credit from a bank when you have 
customers who love your products.. Do you not think they wouldn't mind 
waiting a week or two for that bag they love; When their getting it at a 
discount? Blimey.. With a bit of business initiative the lady could make a 
small fortune.. I really like her business idea.. I just don't like to see 
this spin on things.. People like her CAN grow a small business without the 
'need' for commercial credit.﻿

This is what you get in a country where spending beyond your means on 
credit cards seems the norm, that has an education system that bleeds its 
students dry with insane tuition fees and a healthcare system that's hardly 
1st world.... And WHAT country denies people a bank account??

I don't have student loan debt because here, tuition is affordable (and the 
government chips in, too). I don't own a credit card as I hate the thought 
of spending money that's not on my bank account and I don't have to pay 
through my nose for healthcare because our system is actual 1st world. I 
rent because I can't afford to buy, nor do I want to (there's far less 
pressure to buy a home at a certain age here). I don't drive so no gas 
bills. Keep life simple and enjoy the simple things.

Btw if you're struggling financially, who pays over $100 to go to the 
movies or ice skating?? Priorities people...﻿

Well, I dunno... this video is fucked. They only people I feel bad for are 
the family where the kid has special needs and the dad's got MS. That's a 
double wammy karmic nut shot right there. the other three... well fuck me. 
(I will point out though, that the guy's got the scratch to flash some 
pretty swag eyewear; those Oakley's of his ain't cheap.. I know some pretty 
hard up folk who are glad to get eyeglasses where the frame don't run four 
hunnert bucks .. Just makes me wonder about priorities, ya know?.)

Black girl; single mom and sole financial support for a family, including 
her ailing mom, decides to walk away from a good job to help said ailing 
mom. Admirable, but bound to have unforseen consequences, That was just a 
bad decision. Is anyone really surprised she's in a bind?

The college girl, well, aint she just living the american dream? Give her a 
year or two and she'll be running her own sweat shop, or broke and working 
in someone else's. That's what a $100K art degree gets ya. She's got 
passion and drive, so my money's on her.
Who's left?... oh ya.. dummy with the 'tude. Looking to "buy" in a housing 
market he's not ken to. Fuckin' dummy. Go grow up. Learn to pay your 
fucking bills. Get your shit together, then look at buying a house.

At least, back in the pre-internet days, this drivel would have been 
subject to some critical thinking before being released, but now, on the

comments.text:
Simple ways to save money no matter where in the world you live!

- Walk, bicycle, use public transportation instead of a car. A car costs 
more to have if you don't have money. It may not be the thing you want but 
you'll probably have to consider to get rid of it.

- Don't buy stuff you don't really need. This includes snacks, soda, 
alcohol, candy etc. If you cannot get by, cutting down on these will help a 
lot. It may be lonely on a weekend without something, but you'll sleep good 
knowing you're not in debt.

- Turn off all electronics when you're not using them(i.e away from home). 
This includes the power led on your TV, stereo etc. Don't leave your 
computer running when you're not at home. Also make sure you don't have any 
lamps running.

- Switch out those old lamps for energy saving ones. Their life expectancy 
is generally higher and you'll save money on the electric bill in the long 
run.

- Make a list of groceries you need and if you can, buy them from day to 
day. This ensures, if you live fairly close to a convenient store, that you 
don't have to throw away stuff you may not eat. If you live far away, 
carefully planning your run to the store and what you need to buy, is far 
better than going in there blind. This saves money!

While you do all this your health may improve as well, as you're active a 
lot more than before. Now you eat and buy only what you need and can afford 
to put the little money you have over into savings for a rainy day or a 
treat.

I understand what it's like to not have much, it's not fun and can be 
frustrating to not be able to treat yourself with something now and then. 
But when you don't have any money, it's time to let go of self indulgence 
and think smart.

Hope these few tips helped someone in need out there.

Cheers!

Another thing I came to think of, this probably will hurt the most, but 
it's one of those things that will help you get by, financially, easier. If 
you own a pet, letting it go may be the right thing to do. Maybe ask a 
relative to take care of it until you get back on your feet.﻿

comments.text:
I, as a Dutchman, have lived in the states myself and have an American 
girlfriend, so I have personally experienced some of the differences in 
terms of banking. E.g. at home I don't remember seeing anyone write out a 
check in my lifetime (25) , where as I have American friends my age who use 
them to this day.Regardless I'm still quite shocked by the systems 
explained in this documentary.. In case anyone is interested allow me to 
summarize this from the Dutch perspective. It isn't perfect either but it 
does seem more practical and even fair (as far as basic access/utility of 
banking goes). If you are bored already please save yourself the TL;DR 
effort ;)

So I live in the Netherlands. In order to have a private bank account as a 
non student, you pay an estimated €1,75 to €5 of a service fee per month, 
depending on the bank of your choice. The primary banking card used in the 
Netherlands is an ATM/debit card, Credit Cards have always been a secondary 
choice for the Dutch though it is growing in popularity largely due to 
traveling and non-Dutch online stores which don't include a debit card 
payment option. Paying with a Debit card in a store, or making digital 
transactions through the banks internet banking environment (which every 
bank has) is free/included in the above mentioned service fee and possible 
through your smart phone or your web browser. If I'mm not mistaken, in 
order to get a bank account in the Netherlands, all you need is to be a 
Dutch citizen or have a valid visa/social security number. If  you can 
demonstrate a steady income (1 salary transfer is generally enough) you can 
increase your limit depending on your income. As an example I could set my 
limit to minus €1000,- (max=monthly salary) which won't cost anything as 
long as you maintain a positive balance. If however you dip below €0 you 
will have to make sure you top off your bank account back to 0 and pay the 
interest over the amount you 'borrowed' for the duration that you did. 
These interest rates are relatively high (~12-15%), but after all debt 
should be avoided where possible so some discouragement is probably 
warranted. ﻿

comments.text:
My heart goes out to these people, but even with the bumps of life, their 
situations were preventable. Let's see how, starting at age 17:

1) Go to a local community college. In most states a 2 year degree fulfills 
core requirements and can transfer to a 4 year school. Take a credit load 
that's not too heavy and work full time. Live with your parents and save 
every penny you can.

2) Transfer to a 4 year school, but do your last 2 years over 3-4, part 
time, pay as you go and work a full time job

3) In this time, get a checking account and keep a solid minimum in there. 
Get a FingerHut account to buy holidat gifts as well as birthday gifts, 
apply for their credit, pay it off in full before due date

4) Graduate college. Get a full time job or advance in your existing one. 
Save up and purchase a used car

5) Apply for credit with a store like Value City Furniture. Get 12 months 
terms, get your basic furniture, and pay twice the minimum before the due 
date

6) NEVER pay your utilities late. Ever. Use only a cell phone, look for 
apartments with free heat, don't leave TV/Computers?lights on 24/7

7) Start a savings account. Get a 401k through work, but on your own open a 
savings account and each paycheck pay in until you save 6 months expenses

8) Get a credit card. set a budget for entertainment (restaurants, movies, 
etc) per week and pay with the card. Pay the abalance in full, each month, 
BEFORE the due date. By now you have a PERFECT FICO of 850

9) Don't marry anyone with a FICO under 600, and no debt that will take 
them more than a year to pay off

10) Get your partner's debt paid off before marrying

11) Share an apartment, apply for a car loan for a new car (not expensive) 
and pay it in full or more before the due date.

12) Consult with a financial advisor on a mortgage you can actually afford. 
DO NOT SPEND A PENNY MORE

13) Bump up your 6 months savings while house shopping

14) Buy a house, keep up on the mortgage, pay the balance due every month 
before due date or on due date

15) Once savings is accumulated, consult financial advisor on when you can 
afford a child. Sat a new savings for their college expenses

If everyone did this, there would be no payday or car title loans, no 
crippling debt. Do this and you have perfect credit, a newer car, a house, 
a responsible spouse, emergency funds, and a plan for the future.

WHY THE FUCK IS THIS SO HARD< AMERICANS?﻿

comments.text:
+hollyh1969 I was just thinking how my father was able to support a family 
of 5 on his blue collar job for the phone company. We had two cars and a 
house that had a room for all and much other room to spare.
I live extremely simple- I don't eat out either and I watch my food budget. 
I enjoy this but it is choice. Usually each meal I make is around $2 and I 
only eat twice a day(choice).
But this is really being conscience about my spending- I figure more then 
the average.
If you assume a family of five and each meal is $3 three times a day times 
five is $45. Round it up because you splurge once and a while $50, so for 
the year this is $18,000. This is more then I live on all year(by choice). 
And that's just food and that is also being very careful about your 
spending. 
Something has to give soon- I believe 1/3 of the US is on food stamps. 
Amazing stat considering we are or were the richest nation. 
Maybe its time we rethink our communities and push for more co-op worker 
owned local. Seems with all the big stuff all our money is spent on labor 
from overseas at stores owned by huge conglomerations that suck the money 
out of the community and into some off shore account. 
Your not alone. There are many people in need of a different option. Our 
infrastructure today unfortunately has forgotten about community and sadly 
maybe even our society.

money and never up grade anything...no dishwasher, no heating, no cooling,
